moves.1. d4: A nice tactic sacrifice... the strenght of the London attack.
moves.1... d5 2. Nf3 e6 3. Bf4 Nf6 4. h4 Bb4+: A naive move or a plan?
moves.5. c3: I plan to develop the b1 knight to d2 anyway.
moves.5... Bd6 6. Ne5 Nbd7 7. e3: Still safe. If black exchanges, I have time to defend e5 before black can threat it another time.
moves.7... c5: Good. Black "must" play this move sooner or later in this opening.
moves.8. Qf3: The white pieces are already pointing to the black's kingside.
moves.8... Qb6 9. b3: Black can try some kind of sac here, like c4, 16. b4, Bxb4. White threats Nxf7, KxN, g4... another interesting tactic sac. I can't bet for any of the two sacs, deeper analysis would be necessary.
moves.10. Nd2:
I've done this one since black can attack with c4, threating c4xb3 (which is bad for me, and I cannot defend it easily) or Qb2, if I take the pawn.
Now, by this move, I'm setting the "trick": Nd2-c4, and he cannot take it because Nxc4, trheatening the queen and the bishop at the same time, recovering my piece and a pawn, along with a good position. 
Bd3 was ok, apparently, and if c4, Bc2. But after Ne4, I'm giving him an "attacking" position, I didn't like it. 
Be2 sets the threat Qg3 (for Bh6), but it is easily met, and there are a lot of ways the game can go on. 
I hoped the trick I am building is too deep for him to see. Anyway, not a bad move as it seems to be.
moves.10... h6 11. Be2: This is to avoid Nh4 after Qg3.
moves.11... Nh7 12. Qg3 Bxe5 13. dxe5: The anti natural key move of this opening.
moves.13... Kh8 14. Nf3: I am already seeing the knight sac on g5.
moves.14... f6 15. Bd3 f5: My bishop is blocked, but this allows me to play the sac (Ng5). Black's self blocked pieces are playing in my favour, so I have time for another preparatory move.
moves.16. Qg6 Qd8 17. Ng5: I liked it. It is not a "perfect" sac, but it was too nice not to play it.
moves.18. hxg5 Qe8: Black thinks all his problems will fade by exchanging queens, but it is not so easy.
moves.19... gxh6 20. Qxh6+ Kg8 21. O-O-O: This simple move is definitory. Black is tied to defend the h column, and this allows me to play freely and eventually recover the piece.
moves.21... Qe7: Or Qf7 (the only way to stop the Rh1 threat).
moves.22. Rh1 Qg7 23. Qxe6+: At first, I thought about Bxf5 after the black's move. This is not enough to win. I was sweating, since if the sac doesn't bring me to a victory, I will be playing an idiot.
moves.23... Qf7 24. Qh6 Qg7: Same as before, but, now my e pawn is free...
moves.25. Qxg7+ Kxg7 26. e6:
Another simple move that makes the difference. Black cannot move the knight, because it is mate in few moves. He must have returned the piece, but still with a weak position. 
c4 gives him a breath, but without avoiding the mate threat. If black lets me take the knight, his king would have had a square to escape... but he, apparently, didn't see it.
moves.26... Nb6 27. Be5+: And the forced mate sequence is set.
